nodes.bodyText: Smart.  I wonder if, in anticipation of MPI for arbitrary resource types, should we make this a string?  I suggest String length 40 (like ResourceTable.myResourceType)
Woah.  Nice!

I have mixed feelings about calling this an ExpungeSvc.  Technically it's accurate, but I'm worried future devs might assume it has something to do with the FHIR expunge operation.
IEmpiResetSvc?

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            	 * Given a Target Pid, and a match result, return all links which match these criteria.
          
          
            
            	 * Given a Target Pid, and a match result, return all links that match these criteria.
for numbers that can get big, long is safer than int.
Good call
as above, recommend long over int
What function does this if clause play?  It looks wrong to me.  Can we just remove this if and always execute the block?

Essentially, this ensures that we only reach out to the DB and load actual resources in 100 at a time, as opposed to ONE at a time. It is in effect saying, if we have iterated over 100 pids, or there are no pids remaining, submit the pids to be converted to IBaseResources, and subsequently submitted to EMPI.
Not clear what's "manual" about this...

I suppose when I say manual, I mean a submission that occurs outside of the general interceptor-based framework, which is automatic EMPI processing. Do you have a recommendation for a better word here?
Good catch!
Should be able to drop theTargetType here.  IIdType should include the resource type
Right you are. I was blind, but now I see
maybe move this logic right into myEmpiSearchParamSvc.mapFromCriteria  and remove this method?
Done, but doing this has exposed some ugliness in that class. Left a note in the class docs
use EmpiUtil.supportedTargetType()
I like this method name :-)
expungeAllEmpiLinks() ?
This might not scale when we move to other resource types, but for Person it's totally fine.
good point, might be worthwhile attempting to slice this operation as well. Adding a TODO
Nice reuse of MANUALLY_TRIGGERED.
Rather than @PostConstruct initializing this, can you lazy load it?  95% of installations will never use this.  Some installations do not have a broker.

Just for clarity, you want me to:

Make the bean declaration @lazy,
Move the init code to a standard constructor

Yeah?
Done
I like this syntax!  You should demo it at our next cdr core dev meeting

nice tests!
did you measure coverage?
No, but can do.
you didn't use your fancy new syntax :-)
Ah this was an old test I didn't update!
Tests like this read a bit nicer if they start with a successful read before clearEmpiLinks() is called

+package ca.uhn.fhir.empi.api;
+
+import org.hl7.fhir.instance.model.api.IIdType;
+
+public interface IEmpiBatchService {
+
+	/**
+	 * Submit all eligible resources for EMPI processing.
+	 *  @param theCriteria The FHIR search critieria for filtering the resources to be submitted for EMPI. NOTE:
+	 *                    When using this function, the criteria supplied must be valid for all EMPI types. e.g. , if you
+	 *                    run this with the criteria birthDate=1990-06-28, it will fail, as Practitioner's do not have a birthday.

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+package ca.uhn.fhir.empi.api;
+
+import org.hl7.fhir.instance.model.api.IIdType;
+
+public interface IEmpiBatchService {
+
+	/**
+	 * Submit all eligible resources for EMPI processing.
+	 *  @param theCriteria The FHIR search critieria for filtering the resources to be submitted for EMPI. NOTE:
+	 *                    When using this function, the criteria supplied must be valid for all EMPI types. e.g. , if you
+	 *                    run this with the criteria birthDate=1990-06-28, it will fail, as Practitioner's do not have a birthday.
+	 *                    Use with caution.
+	 *
+	 */
+	int runEmpiOnAllTargetTypes(String theCriteria);
+
+	/**
+	 * Given a type and a search criteria, submit all found resources for EMPI processing.
+	 *
+	 * @param theTargetType the resource type that you wish to execute a search over for submission to EMPI.
+	 * @param theCriteria The FHIR search critieria for filtering the resources to be submitted for EMPI.
+	 * @return the number of resources submitted for EMPI processing.
+	 */
+	int runEmpiOnTargetType(String theTargetType, String theCriteria);
+
+	/**
+	 * Convenience method which calls {@link #runEmpiOnTargetType(String, String)} with the type pre-populated.

@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+package ca.uhn.fhir.empi.api;
+
+import org.hl7.fhir.instance.model.api.IIdType;
+
+public interface IEmpiBatchService {
+
+	/**
+	 * Submit all eligible resources for EMPI processing.
+	 *  @param theCriteria The FHIR search critieria for filtering the resources to be submitted for EMPI. NOTE:
+	 *                    When using this function, the criteria supplied must be valid for all EMPI types. e.g. , if you
+	 *                    run this with the criteria birthDate=1990-06-28, it will fail, as Practitioner's do not have a birthday.
+	 *                    Use with caution.
+	 *
+	 */
+	int runEmpiOnAllTargetTypes(String theCriteria);
+
+	/**
+	 * Given a type and a search criteria, submit all found resources for EMPI processing.
+	 *
+	 * @param theTargetType the resource type that you wish to execute a search over for submission to EMPI.
+	 * @param theCriteria The FHIR search critieria for filtering the resources to be submitted for EMPI.
+	 * @return the number of resources submitted for EMPI processing.
+	 */
+	int runEmpiOnTargetType(String theTargetType, String theCriteria);
+
+	/**
+	 * Convenience method which calls {@link #runEmpiOnTargetType(String, String)} with the type pre-populated.
+	 *
+	 * @param theCriteria The FHIR search critieria for filtering the resources to be submitted for EMPI.
+	 * @return the number of resources submitted for EMPI processing.
+	 */
+	int runEmpiOnPractitionerType(String theCriteria);
+
+	/**
+	 * Convenience method which calls {@link #runEmpiOnTargetType(String, String)} with the type pre-populated.

nodes.bodyText: per my comments in the implementation, change to long and drop the second arg.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+package ca.uhn.fhir.empi.api;
+
+import org.hl7.fhir.instance.model.api.IIdType;
+
+public interface IEmpiBatchService {
+
+	/**
+	 * Submit all eligible resources for EMPI processing.
+	 *  @param theCriteria The FHIR search critieria for filtering the resources to be submitted for EMPI. NOTE:
+	 *                    When using this function, the criteria supplied must be valid for all EMPI types. e.g. , if you
+	 *                    run this with the criteria birthDate=1990-06-28, it will fail, as Practitioner's do not have a birthday.
+	 *                    Use with caution.
+	 *
+	 */
+	int runEmpiOnAllTargetTypes(String theCriteria);
+
+	/**
+	 * Given a type and a search criteria, submit all found resources for EMPI processing.
+	 *
+	 * @param theTargetType the resource type that you wish to execute a search over for submission to EMPI.
+	 * @param theCriteria The FHIR search critieria for filtering the resources to be submitted for EMPI.
+	 * @return the number of resources submitted for EMPI processing.
+	 */
+	int runEmpiOnTargetType(String theTargetType, String theCriteria);
+
+	/**
+	 * Convenience method which calls {@link #runEmpiOnTargetType(String, String)} with the type pre-populated.
+	 *
+	 * @param theCriteria The FHIR search critieria for filtering the resources to be submitted for EMPI.
+	 * @return the number of resources submitted for EMPI processing.
+	 */
+	int runEmpiOnPractitionerType(String theCriteria);
+
+	/**
+	 * Convenience method which calls {@link #runEmpiOnTargetType(String, String)} with the type pre-populated.
+	 *
+	 * @param theCriteria The FHIR search critieria for filtering the resources to be submitted for EMPI.
+	 * @return the number of resources submitted for EMPI processing.
+	 */
+	int runEmpiOnPatientType(String theCriteria);
+
+	/**
+	 * Given an ID and a target type valid for EMPI, manually submit the given ID for EMPI processing.
+	 * @param theId the ID of the resource to process for EMPI.
+	 * @param theTargetType The type of this resource.
+	 * @return the constant `1`, as if this function returns successfully, it will have processed one resource for EMPI.
+	 */
+	int runEmpiOnTarget(IIdType theId, String theTargetType);

nodes.bodyText: nitpick: I'd drop manually
Safer to check theTargetType isn't blank
This is my favourite part of this PR

I strongly recommend you remove this.clear();
If you clear the latch before calling setExpectedCount then you are hiding an entire category of failures from the latch.  Better to expose those failures.
I personally like casual language like this, but I know some people prefer more formal sounding text.

 ```
+
+## Clearing EMPI Links
+
+The `$empi-clear` operation is used to batch-delete EMPI links and related persons from the database. This operation is meant to 
+be used during the rules-tuning phase of the EMPI implementation so that you can quickly test your ruleset.
+It permits the user to essentially "start fresh" without too much fuss.

+## Clearing EMPI Links
+
+The `$empi-clear` operation is used to batch-delete EMPI links and related persons from the database. This operation is meant to 
+be used during the rules-tuning phase of the EMPI implementation so that you can quickly test your ruleset.
+It permits the user to essentially "start fresh" without too much fuss.

nodes.bodyText:
This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            The `$empi-batch-run` operation is used to batch-process patients and practitioners. In normal operation, an interceptor will 
          
          
            
            run EMPI processing over Resources when they are updated or created, but this is not the only context in which you would want to 
          
          
            
            execute EMPI processing against resources. In the rules-tuning phase of your setup, you may use `$empi-batch-run` to quickly apply EMPI rules across multiple Resources.
          
          
            
            Call the `$empi-batch-run` operation to batch-process patients and practitioners. In the rules-tuning phase of your setup, you can use `$empi-batch-run` to apply EMPI rules across multiple Resources.

@@ -447,3 +447,146 @@ This might result in a response such as the following: ] } ``` + +## Clearing EMPI Links + +The `$empi-clear` operation is used to batch-delete EMPI links and related persons from the database. This operation is meant to +be used during the rules-tuning phase of the EMPI implementation so that you can quickly test your ruleset. +It permits the user to essentially "start fresh" without too much fuss. + +After the operation is complete, all targeted EMPI links will be removed from the system, and the Person resources which were involves in those links will be deleted and expunged +from the server. + +This operation takes a single optional Parameter. + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + +
NameTypeCardinalityDescription
resourceTypeString0..1 + The target Resource type you would like to clear. Currently limited to Patient/Practitioner. If omitted, will operate over all links. +
+ +### Example + +Use an HTTP POST to the following URL to invoke this operation: + +```url +http://example.com/$empi-clear +``` + +The following request body could be used: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "resourceType", + "valueString": "Patient" + } ] +} +``` + +This operation returns the number of EMPI links that were cleared. The following is a sample response: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "reset", + "valueDecimal": 5 + } ] +} +``` + +## Batch-creating EMPI Links + +The `$empi-batch-run` operation is used to batch-process patients and practitioners. In normal operation, an interceptor will +run EMPI processing over Resources when they are updated or created, but this is not the only context in which you would want to +execute EMPI processing against resources. In the rules-tuning phase of your setup, you may use `$empi-batch-run` to quickly apply EMPI rules across multiple Resources.

@@ -447,3 +447,146 @@ This might result in a response such as the following: ] } ``` + +## Clearing EMPI Links + +The `$empi-clear` operation is used to batch-delete EMPI links and related persons from the database. This operation is meant to +be used during the rules-tuning phase of the EMPI implementation so that you can quickly test your ruleset. +It permits the user to essentially "start fresh" without too much fuss. + +After the operation is complete, all targeted EMPI links will be removed from the system, and the Person resources which were involves in those links will be deleted and expunged +from the server. + +This operation takes a single optional Parameter. + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + +
NameTypeCardinalityDescription
resourceTypeString0..1 + The target Resource type you would like to clear. Currently limited to Patient/Practitioner. If omitted, will operate over all links. +
+ +### Example + +Use an HTTP POST to the following URL to invoke this operation: + +```url +http://example.com/$empi-clear +``` + +The following request body could be used: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "resourceType", + "valueString": "Patient" + } ] +} +``` + +This operation returns the number of EMPI links that were cleared. The following is a sample response: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "reset", + "valueDecimal": 5 + } ] +} +``` + +## Batch-creating EMPI Links + +The `$empi-batch-run` operation is used to batch-process patients and practitioners. In normal operation, an interceptor will +run EMPI processing over Resources when they are updated or created, but this is not the only context in which you would want to +execute EMPI processing against resources. In the rules-tuning phase of your setup, you may use `$empi-batch-run` to quickly apply EMPI rules across multiple Resources.

@@ -447,3 +447,146 @@ This might result in a response such as the following: ] } ``` + +## Clearing EMPI Links + +The `$empi-clear` operation is used to batch-delete EMPI links and related persons from the database. This operation is meant to +be used during the rules-tuning phase of the EMPI implementation so that you can quickly test your ruleset. +It permits the user to essentially "start fresh" without too much fuss. + +After the operation is complete, all targeted EMPI links will be removed from the system, and the Person resources which were involves in those links will be deleted and expunged +from the server. + +This operation takes a single optional Parameter. + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + +
NameTypeCardinalityDescription
resourceTypeString0..1 + The target Resource type you would like to clear. Currently limited to Patient/Practitioner. If omitted, will operate over all links. +
+ +### Example + +Use an HTTP POST to the following URL to invoke this operation: + +```url +http://example.com/$empi-clear +``` + +The following request body could be used: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "resourceType", + "valueString": "Patient" + } ] +} +``` + +This operation returns the number of EMPI links that were cleared. The following is a sample response: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "reset", + "valueDecimal": 5 + } ] +} +``` + +## Batch-creating EMPI Links + +The `$empi-batch-run` operation is used to batch-process patients and practitioners. In normal operation, an interceptor will +run EMPI processing over Resources when they are updated or created, but this is not the only context in which you would want to +execute EMPI processing against resources. In the rules-tuning phase of your setup, you may use `$empi-batch-run` to quickly apply EMPI rules across multiple Resources. +An important thing to note is that this operation only submits the resources for processing. Actual EMPI processing is run asynchronously, and depending on the size +of the affected bundle of resources, may take some time to complete. + +After the operation is complete, all resources which matched the criteria will have been processed EMPI and will now have at least one EMPI link attached to them.

This operation is meant to +be used during the rules-tuning phase of the EMPI implementation so that you can quickly test your ruleset. +It permits the user to essentially "start fresh" without too much fuss. + +After the operation is complete, all targeted EMPI links will be removed from the system, and the Person resources which were involves in those links will be deleted and expunged +from the server. + +This operation takes a single optional Parameter. + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + +
NameTypeCardinalityDescription
resourceTypeString0..1 + The target Resource type you would like to clear. Currently limited to Patient/Practitioner. If omitted, will operate over all links. +
+ +### Example + +Use an HTTP POST to the following URL to invoke this operation: + +```url +http://example.com/$empi-clear +``` + +The following request body could be used: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "resourceType", + "valueString": "Patient" + } ] +} +``` + +This operation returns the number of EMPI links that were cleared. The following is a sample response: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "reset", + "valueDecimal": 5 + } ] +} +``` + +## Batch-creating EMPI Links + +The `$empi-batch-run` operation is used to batch-process patients and practitioners. In normal operation, an interceptor will +run EMPI processing over Resources when they are updated or created, but this is not the only context in which you would want to +execute EMPI processing against resources. In the rules-tuning phase of your setup, you may use `$empi-batch-run` to quickly apply EMPI rules across multiple Resources. +An important thing to note is that this operation only submits the resources for processing. Actual EMPI processing is run asynchronously, and depending on the size +of the affected bundle of resources, may take some time to complete. + +After the operation is complete, all resources which matched the criteria will have been processed EMPI and will now have at least one EMPI link attached to them. + +This operation takes a single optional Parameter when used at the Resource of Server level.

The following is a sample response: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "reset", + "valueDecimal": 5 + } ] +} +``` + +## Batch-creating EMPI Links + +The `$empi-batch-run` operation is used to batch-process patients and practitioners. In normal operation, an interceptor will +run EMPI processing over Resources when they are updated or created, but this is not the only context in which you would want to +execute EMPI processing against resources. In the rules-tuning phase of your setup, you may use `$empi-batch-run` to quickly apply EMPI rules across multiple Resources. +An important thing to note is that this operation only submits the resources for processing. Actual EMPI processing is run asynchronously, and depending on the size +of the affected bundle of resources, may take some time to complete. + +After the operation is complete, all resources which matched the criteria will have been processed EMPI and will now have at least one EMPI link attached to them. + +This operation takes a single optional Parameter when used at the Resource of Server level. + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + +
NameTypeCardinalityDescription
criteriaString0..1 + The search critiera used to filter resources. +
+ +### Example + +This operation can be executed at the Server level, Resource level, or Instance level. +Use an HTTP POST to the following URL to invoke this operation with criteria:

nodes.bodyText: Nice!
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -447,3 +447,146 @@ This might result in a response such as the following: ] } ``` + +## Clearing EMPI Links + +The `$empi-clear` operation is used to batch-delete EMPI links and related persons from the database. This operation is meant to +be used during the rules-tuning phase of the EMPI implementation so that you can quickly test your ruleset. +It permits the user to essentially "start fresh" without too much fuss. + +After the operation is complete, all targeted EMPI links will be removed from the system, and the Person resources which were involves in those links will be deleted and expunged +from the server. + +This operation takes a single optional Parameter. + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + +
NameTypeCardinalityDescription
resourceTypeString0..1 + The target Resource type you would like to clear. Currently limited to Patient/Practitioner. If omitted, will operate over all links. +
+ +### Example + +Use an HTTP POST to the following URL to invoke this operation: + +```url +http://example.com/$empi-clear +``` + +The following request body could be used: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "resourceType", + "valueString": "Patient" + } ] +} +``` + +This operation returns the number of EMPI links that were cleared. The following is a sample response: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "name": "reset", + "valueDecimal": 5 + } ] +} +``` + +## Batch-creating EMPI Links + +The `$empi-batch-run` operation is used to batch-process patients and practitioners. In normal operation, an interceptor will +run EMPI processing over Resources when they are updated or created, but this is not the only context in which you would want to +execute EMPI processing against resources. In the rules-tuning phase of your setup, you may use `$empi-batch-run` to quickly apply EMPI rules across multiple Resources. +An important thing to note is that this operation only submits the resources for processing. Actual EMPI processing is run asynchronously, and depending on the size +of the affected bundle of resources, may take some time to complete. + +After the operation is complete, all resources which matched the criteria will have been processed EMPI and will now have at least one EMPI link attached to them. + +This operation takes a single optional Parameter when used at the Resource of Server level. + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + +
NameTypeCardinalityDescription
criteriaString0..1 + The search critiera used to filter resources. +
+ +### Example + +This operation can be executed at the Server level, Resource level, or Instance level. +Use an HTTP POST to the following URL to invoke this operation with criteria: + +```url +http://example.com/$empi-batch-run +http://example.com/Patient/$empi-batch-run +http://example.com/Practitioner/$empi-batch-run +``` + +The following request body could be used: + +```json +{ + "resourceType": "Parameters", + "parameter": [ { + "criteria": "", + "valueString": "birthDate=2020-07-28" + } ] +} +``` +This operation returns the number of resources that were submitted for EMPI processing. Oops missed this the first time around.
Please remove the try/catch.  This needs to throw an exception if it fails so the test fails.
As written, junit has no way of knowing the assertion failed.
